revisions.rev:
{{About|the Australian television network formerly known as PRIME Television|the New Zealand television channel|Prime (New Zealand)|the Canadian television channel formerly known as Prime|TVtropolis}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = PRIME7 | logofile = Prime7.svg | logosize = 200px | logocaption = Prime7 Logo | launch = 17 March 1962 | picture format = [[576i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]]),
[[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | owner = [[Prime Media Group Limited]] | slogan = ''OnePlace'' | web = [http://www.prime7.com.au/ prime7.com.au] | country = [[Australia]] | language = [[English language|English]] | former names = '''Prime Television'''
(1988 - 2011) | broadcast area = Regional [[NEN (TV station)|New South Wales]],
[[CBN (Australian TV station)|Australian Capital Territory]],
Regional [[AMV (TV station)|Victoria]], [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] | terr serv 1 = [[Analog television|Analogue]] | terr chan 1 = ''Tuned to various frequencies'' | terr serv 2 = [[Standard-definition television|SD Digital]] | terr chan 2 = Channel 6 | cable serv 1 = [[TransACT|TransTV Digital]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 6 | cable serv 2 = [[Neighbourhood Cable|NC Digital]] | cable chan 2 = Channel 7 }} '''PRIME7''' is an Australian [[Television broadcasting in Australia|television network]] owned by [[Prime Media Group Limited]]. Prime Television launched on 17 March 1962 as ''[[CBN (Australian TV station)|CBN/CWN]]'' in [[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]] and [[Dubbo]], [[New South Wales]], and has since expanded to cover regional [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and the [[Australian Capital Territory]] as a [[Seven Network]] affiliate. PRIME's administration and broadcast facilities are based in [[Canberra]], alongside the network's parent company Prime Media Group Limited and the playout facilities for the [[Golden West Network]].{{cite web |url= http://www.primetv.com.au/files/1/33/84/37/PrimeAnnualReportFinalWeb.pdf |title= 2005 Annual Report |accessdate= 17 September 2007 |publisher= [[Prime Television Limited]] }} ==History== ===Origins=== Prime Television originally began as a group of separate stations and networks - ''Midstate Television'' in [[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]], [[Dubbo]] and [[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]], ''[[AMV (TV station)|RVN/AMV]]'' in [[Albury, New South Wales|Albury]] and [[Wagga Wagga]], and ''NEN/ECN'' in [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] and [[Taree, New South Wales|Taree]].{{cite web |url= http://www.austvhistory.com/prime/preaggregation.htm |title= Prime Television 1960s-1980s |accessdate= 17 September 2007 |author= Brooklyn Ross-Hulands |publisher= AusTVHistory }} [[CBN (Australian TV station)|CBN-8]] [[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]] began on 17 March 1962, followed by [[CBN (Australian TV station)|CWN-6]] Dubbo on 1 December 1965. The two stations were both licensed to ''Country Broadcasting Services'' (also the owner of radio station [[2GZ]] in Orange). CWN-6 was a direct relay of CBN-8 - this meant that the two stations formed the country's first regional network, CBN/CWN. At the same time, [[AMV (TV station)|RVN-2]] [[Wagga Wagga, New South Wales|Wagga Wagga]] began on 19 June 1964, and [[MTN (TV station)|MTN-9]] [[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]] began on 15 December 1965. The two stations merged in 1971 as the ''Riverina and North East Victoria Television Service Pty Ltd'', ''RVN/AMV'' on air. In northern New South Wales, NEN-9 [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] began transmission on 27 September 1965, with a relay in [[Armidale, New South Wales|Armidale]] (NEN-1, later NEN-10) on 15 July 1966. ECN-8 [[Taree, New South Wales|Taree]] started on 27 May 1966. At one stage, ECN-8 was tied NRN-11 [[Coffs Harbour, New South Wales|Coffs Harbour]] (now owned by [[Southern Cross Broadcasting]] as [[Southern Cross Ten]]), however the two stations split. NEN later merged with ECN as ''NEN-9/ECN-8''. ===Television 6-8-9=== As a result of the financial difficulties that many independent stations faced, MTN-9 joined CWN-6 and CBN-8 to form ''Television 6, 8, 9'' in 1973 (later known as ''Midstate Television''). Relays were launched in [[Portland, New South Wales|Portland]], [[Lithgow, New South Wales|Lithgow]], [[Mudgee]], [[Cobar, New South Wales|Cobar]], [[Kandos, New South Wales|Kandos]] and [[Rylstone, New South Wales|Rylstone]] and [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]]. [[Colour television]] was introduced at the same time as the rest of the country, on 1 March 1975 - one of the single most expensive processes undertaken by CBN to date. The station was a prominent broadcaster of local sporting events including [[Tennis]] and [[Rugby football|Rugby]]. In 1979 a documentary titled ''Goin' Down The Road'', about the 1978 National Rodeo Titles won the network a [[Logie award]] for an 'Outstanding Contribution by a Regional Station'. Midstate produced a number of local programs, including the ''Weekend Report'', ''Early Shift'', ''Rural Roundup'' and ''Around the Schools''. Since 1968 CBN was able to access the [[Postmaster-General's Department|Postmaster General]]'s microwave link for national news and other major events. ===Aggregation=== [[Image:Prime, 2WG and Star FM broadcasting studios.jpg|thumb|Former RVN now (CBN-2) the Prime Television studios in Wagga Wagga]] Midstate Television was bought out by media magnate Paul Ramsay's Ramcorp Ltd. in October 1987. It was soon merged with Ramcorp's other stations, ''RVN/AMV'' and ''NEN/ECN''. The name ''The Prime Network'' had been in use since 1986. By 1988 the network began to show increased [[Seven Network]] programming in readiness for [[Regional television in Australia#Aggregation|aggregation]]. When aggregation took place, Prime began broadcasting to both southern [[New South Wales]] and northern [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. Transmission problems meant that aggregation in southern [[New South Wales]] took place in two stages - first the [[Australian Capital Territory]] and [[South Coast (New South Wales)|NSW south coast]] on 31 March 1989, followed by [[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]], [[Dubbo]], and [[Wagga Wagga]] on 31 December 1989. These changes led to the de-merger of RVN-AMV, with RVN becoming CBN-2. [[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]] remained a one-station market, however instead of taking programming from Prime in line with the network's other stations, [[MTN (TV station)|MTN-9]] relayed programming mainly from [[WIN Television]] in southern New South Wales. A supplementary license, AMN-31, was successfully bid for by MTN in 1996, providing a relay of Prime Television.{{cite web |url= http://www.austvhistory.com/prime/90s.htm |title= Prime Television 1990s |accessdate= 17 September 2007 |author= Brooklyn Ross-Hulands |publisher= AusTVHistory }} Soon after the station was purchased by [[WIN Television]], which undertook a number of minor changes - mainly changing the news service to [[WIN News]], and using entirely WIN branding. AMN-31 remains a relay of Prime. Similarly, the [[Mildura, Victoria|Mildura]] license area remained separate from the remainder of Victoria, albeit with a single station, STV-8, later bought out by [[WIN Television]] in 1996.{{cite journal | author = Tanner, Stephen | title = The Rise and Fall of Edmund Rouse | publisher = [[University of Queensland]] | year = 1995 | url = http://eprint.uq.edu.au/archive/00000280/01/tanner95.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 19 August 2007 }} In 1997 Prime was successful in bidding for a new license for the area at a cost of $3.2 million.{{cite web |url= http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/1001/pc=PC_90532 |title= New Commercial TV licences for Darwin and Mildura |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |date= 29 October 1996 |publisher= [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] }} PTV-31 began broadcasting the following year. Although advertising revenue increased post-aggregation, local programming declined as a result of the costs incurred by the network's expansion - an estimated $45 million had been spent by Ramcorp during and in the lead-up to aggregation. After losses of $50 million, it was not until 1993 that the renamed [[Prime Television Limited]] posted a profit.{{cite news |title=Prime Returns from the Brink |url=http://www.uow.edu.au/arts/sts/bmartin/dissent/documents/health/ramsay_early.html |work=[[Australian Financial Review]] |publisher= |date=25 August 1993 |accessdate=15 September 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070910103323/http://www.uow.edu.au/arts/sts/bmartin/dissent/documents/health/ramsay_early.html |archivedate = 10 September 2007}} In November 1996, PRIME's parent company, [[Prime Television Limited]], purchased the [[Golden West Network]], a merged group of four stations; BTW-3 [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]], VEW-8 [[Kalgoorlie, Western Australia|Kalgoorlie]], GTW-11 [[Geraldton, Western Australia|Geraldton]] and GSW-9 [[Albany, Western Australia|Albany]].{{cite news | last = Kidman | first = Matthew | title = Prime buys Golden West | publisher = Sydney Morning Herald | page = 29 | date = 13 November 1996 }} Western Australia, similar to Griffith and Mildura, remained a one-station commercial market until 1999 when GWN became a [[Seven Network]] affiliate, after [[WIN Television]] began transmission as an affiliate of both the [[Nine Network]] and [[Network Ten]]. The network began to expand into New Zealand in 1997, when a number of licenses were purchased from [[United Christian Broadcasters]] for an estimated $3.6 million.{{cite news | title = Packer to boost Prime Television | publisher = The Press | page = 17 | date = 22 December 2001 }} [[Prime Television New Zealand]] began broadcasting on 30 August 1998, with a nightly local news program in both [[Waikato]] and [[Christchurch]]. Prime also expanded into [[Argentina]] with the purchase of the [[Canal 9 (Argentina)|Canal 9]] network.{{cite news | last = Kidman | first = Matthew | title = Prime TV buys and sells in Argentina | publisher = Sydney Morning Herald | page = 27 | date = 16 December 1997 }} ===2000s=== [[File:Prime Television Broadcast Centre.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Prime Television Broadcast Centre in [[Watson, Australian Capital Territory]]]] The renamed Argentine network Azul TelevisiÃ³n was sold for $108 million in early 2000 due to lower-than-expected performance.{{cite news | last = Schulze | first = Jane | title = Prime offloads Azul for $108m | publisher = Sydney Morning Herald | page = 27 | date = 17 March 2000 }} During the same year, Prime benefited greatly from its affiliation with the [[Seven Network]] throughout its carriage of the [[2000 Summer Olympics]] in [[Sydney]]. The network's relationship with Seven was further developed throughout the early 2000s, leading to the unsuccessful introduction of ''7onPrime'' branding for [[Seven Network]]-produced programs.{{cite web |url= http://www.austvhistory.com/prime/00s.htm |title= Prime Television 2000s |accessdate= 17 September 2007 |author= Brooklyn Ross-Hulands |publisher= AusTVHistory }} Local news bulletins for [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]], the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Canberra]], and [[Wollongong, New South Wales|Wollongong]] were axed in 2001 due to falling ratings and the anticipated costs of the switch to [[digital television]]. {{cite news | last = Macguire | first = Toby | title = Regional TV news gets axe | work = The Daily Telegraph | page = 17 | date = 9 June 2001 }} This, and the closure of a number of news bulletins by [[Southern Cross Broadcasting]], prompted the [[Australian Broadcasting Authority]] to investigate the adequacy of regional news services{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/stories/s423564.htm |title=ABA to hold investigation into adequacy of regional news |accessdate=1 September 2007 |date= 21 September 2001 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] }} The ABA later mandated that stations broadcast a minimum level of local content, based on a points system - two points per minute for local news, and one point per minute for other local content, excluding paid advertisements.{{cite web |url=http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/1001/pc=PC_91497 |title= Regional television exceeds local content quotas |accessdate=1 September 2007 |date= 7 September 2004 |publisher=[[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] }} Prime formed a partnership with the [[Nine Network]] (affiliated in Australia to competitor [[WIN Television]]), giving its owner, [[PBL Media]] the option to purchase a 50% share of [[Prime Television New Zealand]] in return for access to original programming, and cross-promotion in PBL's New Zealand magazine titles.{{cite press release |title=Nine Network Australia Formally Commences New Zealand Partnership with Prime Television Australia |publisher=[[PBL Media]] |date= 18 February 2002 |url=http://www.pbl.com.au/nine_network_australia_formally_commences_new_zealand_partnership_with_prime_television_australia.htm |accessdate=2 September 2007}} Following this, Prime Television New Zealand began to take on branding and programming similar to that of the [[Nine Network]]. In November 2005, [[Prime Television New Zealand]] was purchased by [[subscription television]] provider [[SKY Network Television]] for $[[New Zealand dollar|NZ]]30 million, completed after approval by New Zealand's [[Commerce Commission]] in February 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.primetv.co.nz/default.asp?t=4 |title= Corporate - About Us |accessdate=1 September 2007 |year=2006 |work=[[Prime Television New Zealand]] |publisher=[http://www.primetv.co.nz/ primetv.co.nz] }} [[Mildura Digital Television]], a digital-only station in [[Mildura, Victoria|Mildura]] began transmissions in 2006 as a joint venture between [[Prime Television Limited]] and [[WIN Corporation]]. [[Section 38A|Section 38B]] of the ''Broadcasting Services Act'' allowed for the provision of a third station owned by either one or both existing networks. MDT is a direct relay of [[ATV-10|Ten Melbourne]], albeit with local advertising. Prime Television announced on 21 December 2009 that it would start broadcasting [[7TWO]] on 23 December 2009. ===2010s=== On 25 September 2010, Prime began transmission of the new HD digital channel [[7mate]] aimed at men 16-49. The first program to be broadcast was the drawn [[2010 AFL Grand Final]]. On 15 January 2011, Prime Media Group reported that Prime and [[Golden West Network|GWN]] were to rebrand as Prime7 and GWN7 respectively. The news bulletins has changed to Prime7 News and GWN7 News, during that, 7TWO and 7MATE dropped the "Prime" logo on the multichannels. Prime and GWN relaunched on 16 January 2011 at 6:00pm.http://www.prime7.com.au ==Programming== Prime's programming schedule is almost identical to that of its metropolitan affiliate, the [[Seven Network]], with some differences. Since the network's inception it has featured a broad range of original local programming, currently including children's program ''The Saturday Club'', music show ''X:Press'' as well as community service segment ''Prime InfoNet'', a series of short updates listing local community events. Prime's overnight schedule also differs from the Seven Network feed, containing infomercials from Danoz Direct, Home Shopping, and a feed from pay television channel [[Expo Channel|Expo]].{{cite web |url= http://www.primetv.com.au/i-cms.isp?page=1.8.108 |title= Prime Television: TV Guide |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= [http://www.primetv.com.au/ primetv.com.au] }} Past programming from Prime Television has been recognised nationally, with some local productions winning the [[Logie Award]] for 'Outstanding Contribution by a Regional Television Station'. The network has won Logies for ''Goin' Down The Road'' (CBN-8, 1979),{{cite web |url= http://www.australiantelevision.net/awards/logie1978_81.html |title= Australian Television: 1978-1981 Logie Awards |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= Australian Television Information Archive }} ''Naturally'' (NEN-9/ECN-8, 1984),{{cite web |url= http://www.australiantelevision.net/awards/logie1982_85.html |title= Australian Television: 1982-1985 Logie Awards |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= Australian Television Information Archive }} ''Stranded'' (Prime Television, 1993),{{cite web |url= http://www.australiantelevision.net/awards/logie1990_93.html |title= Australian Television: 1990-1993 Logie Awards |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= Australian Television Information Archive }} ''Rest in Peace'' (Prime Television, 1994),{{cite web |url= http://www.australiantelevision.net/awards/logie1994_97.html |title= Australian Television: 1994-1997 Logie Awards |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= Australian Television Information Archive }} and ''No Time For Frailty'' (Prime Television, 1996). ===News=== [[File:Prime7news.png|thumb|right|The current Prime7 news logo]] [[File:Prime News logo.svg|thumb|right|The Prime News logo used 2001-2011]] [[File:Mayor Kerry Pascoe.jpg|thumb|Prime News reporter, Ashlea Brown, interviewing Wagga Wagga Mayor Kerry Pascoe]] ''Prime7 News'' is the network's local news service. Full bulletins are produced for the towns and surrounding regions originally covered by the stations "Midstate 6,8,9 Television", [[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]]/[[Dubbo]], "RVN-2/AMV-4", [[Albury, New South Wales|Albury]]/[[Wodonga, Victoria|Wodonga]] and "9/8 Television" (NEN-9/ECN-8) [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]]/[[Taree, New South Wales|Taree]], prior to the [[Regional television in Australia#Aggregation|aggregation]]. of regional television services in New South Wales that occurred in the early 1990s. In other areas two-minute news updates are shown at various times of the day. ''Prime7 News'' is presented live, from local studios weeknightly at 6pm in most areas, with the exception of Orange and Wagga Wagga where both bulletins presented from Canberra,{{cite news|title=TV news decision ends an era|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/08/06/2975258.htm|accessdate=17 August 2010|newspaper=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=6 August 2010}}{{cite news|title=Prime airs its first Canberra bulletin|accessdate=17 August 2010|newspaper=The Daily Advertiser|date=17 August 2010|page=3}} followed by a delayed bulletin of ''[[Seven News]]''. The Albury and Orange ''Prime7 News'' bulletins are presented by [[Daniel Gibson (presenter)|Daniel Gibson]] with Madelaine Collignon presenting the weather. Elspeth Taylor and sport presenter Bill North present the Tamworth and North Coast bulletins, while in Wagga Wagga the news presenter is presented by Doug Hogan. Each region has its own reporter, such as [[Port Macquarie]]'s [[Amanda Douglas]]. News bulletins for the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]], [[Canberra]], and [[Wollongong, New South Wales|Wollongong]] were axed in 2001 (in the Gold Coast's case, 2000). At the same time, the network's [[Moree]] news bureau, which provided stories for the [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] bulletin, was closed. This, as well as the closure of bulletin by [[Southern Cross Ten]] in parts of [[Queensland]] and [[New South Wales]], prompted an investigation by the [[Australian Broadcasting Authority]]. New rules were later set out requiring regional stations to offer minimum levels of local content, over a six-week period.{{cite web |url= http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/pc=PC_91817 |title= Local content conditions on regional commercial television broadcasters |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]] }} Two-minute news updates were introduced to Newcastle, Wollongong and Canberra in 2004. These updates are presented by Natalie Forrest, [[Daniel Gibson (presenter)|Daniel Gibson]] (weather), Madelaine Collignon (fill-in weather) and Renee Bogatko (fill-in news). Weekend weathers to the markets of Newcastle/Hunter Valley, Tamworth, North Coast NSW and South East QLD/Gold Coast are presented by Craig Moore. A number of well-known [[news presenters]] and television personalities began their careers at Prime7 News, including former ''[[Today (Australian TV program)|Today]]'' co-host [[Jessica Rowe]],{{cite web |url= http://www.ovations.com.au/presenter_detail/Jessica_Rowe/27796/1 |title= Jessica Rowe |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= Ovations! }} ''[[The Morning Show (TV program)|The Morning Show]]'' co-host [[Kylie Gillies]],{{cite web |url= http://au.blogs.yahoo.com/themorningshow/2/kylie-gillies |title= The Morning Show: Kylie Gillies |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= [[Yahoo! 7]] }} and ''[[It Takes Two (Australian TV series)|It Takes Two]]'' host [[Grant Denyer]].{{cite web |url= http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/hosts/ |title= It Takes Two Hosts |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= [[Yahoo! 7]] }} Kerryn Johnston presented Prime's Wollongong bulletin until it was axed, when she moved to [[WIN Television]] where she currently co-anchors the network's [[Illawarra, New South Wales|Illawarra]] bulletins.{{cite web |url= http://www.wintv.com.au/presenters.php?p_id=99 |title= WIN TV Presenters: Kerryn Johnston |accessdate= 15 September 2007 |publisher= [[WIN Television]] |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070831085146/http://www.wintv.com.au/presenters.php?p_id=99 |archivedate = 31 August 2007}} ==Availability== Prime Television is available in [[analog television|analog]] [[PAL]] and [[Standard definition television|standard definition]] [[Digital terrestrial television|digital]] format. Since June 2007 a [[1080i]] [[High-definition television|high definition]] simulcast has also been available, replacing the network's former [[576p]] service.{{cite web | url = http://www.dba.org.au/index.asp?sectionID=58&newsID=966&display=news | title = Prime Television announces HD shift to 1080i format | accessdate = 29 June 2007 | date = 28 June 2007 | work = Prime Television | publisher = dba.org.au }} Prime is viewed mainly through [[free-to-air]] [[Terrestrial television|terrestrial]] [[transmitter]]s, although [[Subscription television|subscription]] [[Cable television#Australia|cable]] also provided by [[TransACT]] and [[Neighbourhood Cable]] in the [[Australian Capital Territory]] and [[Ballarat, Victoria|Ballarat]], respectively.{{cite web | url = http://www.transact.com.au/television/channels.aspx | title = TransTV Channel Lineup | accessdate = 19 August 2007 | publisher = [[TransACT]] }}{{cite web | url = http://www.ncable.net.au/_site/products.asp?cat=4 | title = Neighbourhood Cable Channel Lineup | accessdate = 19 August 2007 | publisher = [[Neighbourhood Cable]] }} Prime broadcasts to southern [[New South Wales]] through stations based in [[CBN (Australian TV station)|Orange]] and [[CBN (Australian TV station)|Dubbo]], northern [[New South Wales]] from stations in [[NEN (TV station)|Tamworth]] and [[NEN (TV station)|Taree]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] from its [[Albury, New South Wales|Albury]]-[[Wodonga, Victoria|Wodonga]]-based station [[AMV (TV station)|AMV]], and [[Mildura, Victoria|Mildura]] via [[PTV (TV station)|PTV]]. Prime is relayed to [[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]] by the [[WIN Television]]-owned supplementary station [[MTN (TV station)|AMN]]. ==Logos== Prime Television became a network in November 1988, witha shared logo produced and used across the regional stations, featuring the word ''Prime Television'' above an outlined rectangle. Aggregation occurred across the network on 31 December 1989, along with the introduction of a green logo featuring the word ''Prime'' with the letter ''i'' dotted with a globe. This logo was used across the network until 1991, when a new gold logo was introduced. Following a decade in use, 2001 saw the launch of a new simplified yellow logo, with the removal of the circle. This logo has been used since, and was launched concurrently with a similarly design logo on the [[Golden West Network]]. Following the 2011 relaunch, a new logo was introduced which features the [[Seven Network]] logo. File:Prime 1988.jpeg|1988–89 File:PrimeTelevision2001.svg|2001–16 January 2011 ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Television in Australia}} *[http://iprime.com.au/ iPrime] {{Prime Media Group Limited}} {{Australian free-to-air television networks}} {{good article}} [[Category:Australian television networks]] [[Category:Prime Media Group Limited]] [[fr:Prime Television]]
